reviewText:
'Do you recommend this game,' Steam asks me. I do, emphatically. I hope this anecdote from an in-game multiplayer experience I had will explain why. Prepare yourself for ARMA2: The Review: The Movie.

Spring, 2011; early in my ARMA career, first tour of duty after a Steam Sale. I'm a fairly fresh recruit, seasoned with a couple dozen game-hours spent trudging through an expansive and swampy learning curve. Spent today at work, drove home, made dinner, cleaned up; it's Game-O'clock. Steam. ARMA2. Launch. Menu surfing, looking for multiplayer. Server browser hits my face with lists of information. -AWP-Warfare Capture the Island mode looks appealing tonight. Played it a couple times before, and I feel comfortable with the basics by now. Server connection established.

Click! I'm in, filling the boots of a digital NATO badass. Apparently, international treaty organisations occasionally require the service of men with guns. Disturbing thought, but I'm no politician. I'm just a nobody with a rifle, taking orders that filter down the food chain. Those orders fill my mind now. Objective: town. Location: nearby...as the crow flies. Heh, the team's commander does have airborne technology unlocked, I just don't have the cash to buy a lift yet. Looks like I'm taking the scenic route. A quick check of my map tells me I'm at one of our hidden frontier bases and that there's two whole mountains between me and the nearby town. Great... I'll be taking the scenic route to the scenic route. The map tells me more: several of my team members and their A.I. controlled task forces are currently approaching the town. I'm already late for the party :(

Might as well bring the fireworks.

The base I'm at has only an armour factory and infantry barracks, but both will well suit my rapidly forming battle plan. I'm thinking heavy calibre fire support from high ground, overlooking the town. The topographic information in the map shows that the road I'll be taking is nestled around a minor hill as it approaches the town. Perfect. I'll park two BMPs there and they'll provide overwatch of the whole area while my comrades finish their capture of the town. An LAV will ferry me and one squad of A.I. infantry to the combat zone. I spend the required funds and set the plan in action.

Wait a tick, BeatYourHeadIn, are you telling me you actually have to plan how you’re going to get your troops and equipment from point A to point B in ARMA2? Logistics in a game!? Yes, actual logistics...in a game with a map so FRIGGIN’ big you need to employ logistical planning skills to see any sort of success. And it's not boring!

Back to the story. Formation of a military convoy. A few orders issued to my A.I. controlled task force later and the BMPs are on point while I lounge in the command chair of the LAV at the rear of the column. I man the turret-mounted automatic grenade launcher, a devastating weapon. Its barrel is ominously pointed at and tracking a lollygagging friendly player as my convoy departs base. Yeah, that's right chump, make one wrong move and I'll end you! Though itching to test the power of my new toy, I decide it's not worth getting banned over.  I let my teammate live, for now.

The A.I. drivers of my convoy are as dim as a new moon, but I can fine tune my plans and keep up with current events while they drive. It's an 10 to 15 minute (realtime) drive that negotiates a winding mountain pass through an elegant evergreen forest. These are backroads, unpaved; enemy forces unlikely to be using this route. I feel secure enough that I spend most of the trip looking at the map, reading topography, lanes of fire, positions of friendlies. I smile when I realize I could probably minimize ARMA2 and play a few rounds of Counterstrike while my convoy travels.

Dying immediately is certainly the last thing I'm worried about as I crest the peak of the second mountain.

Suddenly: EXPLOSION..DEAFENING SOUND..FROM BEHIND..MASSIVE DETONATION..JESUS H. CHRIST WHERE IS THAT VOLUME KNOB! What is going on here!?

My turret pans to the rear of the LAV. The sight, what a sight...I'll never forget. Fire. Wall. 60? 70 feet tall? A wall. Of fire. Taller than the trees in the forest, literally FILLS my view from left to right. There is nothing in view except the fire. I'm in awe. Confused. Shaken. I've seen 'splosions in this game before, BUT NEVER LIKE THAT! Did somebody tried to nuke me FFS!? I know there's no nukes in this game mode, so...

Over the cacophany of destruction: the scream of jet engines. Very close. As the flames die down, a large shape traverses the air over the crest of the crag. Airframe, Sukhoi configuration. Enemy. Wing tilted down slightly; canopy visible. I know he's surveying the carnage below him. Hunting me. Cursing his aim when he sees the LAV still intact. I feel small, molecule small; what I just witnessed was caused by his war machine. Napalm bombs. Heavy ordinance. Whatever it was, it dealt complete destruction to that forest.

Understand this, readers: in this game, air superiority is a literal phrase. Air is SUPERIOR in this game. This isn't your Battlefield oh look I can shoot a few rockets from my jet fighter and maybe kill one or two goofs on the ground and then reload (because reloading rockets on a flying jet makes a lot of sense) and kill a couple more goofs" experience. No! In ARMA your aircraft can have a payload of more than a hundred devastating rockets and you can fire 'em full auto like a machine gun and destroy an entire town worth of goofs on the ground if you wanted to. Ha! Forget about balance! This is the real life Shiznit. Modern air forces don't invest heavily in war planes because they're "balanced". They invest in them because they can kill a hell of a lot of people quickly! ARMA2 knows this. Simply put

reviewText:
This Review will be the same for Operation Arrowhead

Pros
- Actual Military Simulation
- Realistic Design for both Takistan and Chernarus
- Decent Singleplayer Campaigns
- Great Ingame Sound Effects
- Realistic Scenarios and Military Stategies
- Multiplayer is very Mod-Friendly and full of options
- Fleshed Out Ingame Menus to adjust pretty much everything

Cons
- DayZ destroyed the community (More Below)

So my only real con with Arma II and Operation Arrowhead is that the community that remained on Arma II, mostly a few small Warfare and Domination Communities, is now dead and has moved on to Arma III, that is understandable. Arrowhead is a different story. The game is still very alive, the issue with Arrowhead is the community is ruined. DayZ brought around some of the worst types of people. Before DayZ Griefers were very rare, now they are everywhere and the worst part is, they hack and destory servers and get accounts banned. The game in its current online state is poor, and that is sad, very sad, especially since I remember when it wasn't like this. Arma III is shaping up to be a much better game than what we currently have in Arma II, and the community seems to be holding together, more than likely because DayZ is now a standalone game. My gripes are more personal and subject to opinion though. Both Arrowhead and Arma II are amazing Military Simulators. The Singleplayer is realistic, and top notch. Nothing but the Original Operation Flashpoint can really stand up to it.

9/10 - Both great titles, but I would recommend not buying them anymore and just purchasing Arma III until maybe the DayZ fad finally dies out.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs
3 tablespoons sugar
3 tablespoons melted butter
40 ounces softened cream cheese
1 cup sugar
3 tablespoons flour
1 tablespoon vanilla
1 cup sour cream
4 eggs

Directions:
For The base:.
If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.
Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.
Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.
For the batter:.
Make sure everything is at room temperature.
Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.
Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.
Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.
Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.
Release the sides of the springform.
Eat.

reviewText:
I'm going to try and keep this simple and to the point. I am not much for words but I'll try to condense what I think about this game.

Pros:
1. Huge potential. Large seamless maps. You can drive, fly or run across km after km. Towns, roads etc.. Basically entire detailed islands.
2. Great military sim taking advantage of the above. Realistic damage from small arms as well as vehicle weapons.
3. Lots of realistic military vehicles and aircraft. Even boats.
4. Multiplayer is fun, especially coop.
5. Speaking of multiplayer, Dayz mod is something special. Very fun and you can waste hours and hours in it.
6. The single player story is alright, I guess. Nothing to tell mom about.

Cons:
1. Bugs, glitches, more bugs. Absolutely unbearable, game breaking, punch your monitor and throw your computer out the window kind of bugs. Because you can only save 2 times per mission and the mission mught be very well broken before your first save and you won't know it until the end, which can take 1 hour or more if you take your time like me. All sorts of bugs. AI pathfinding drives your teammates vehicles off of cliffs. Mission scripts break and you can't complete the mission. You may fall through the floor and injure yourself badly or die (especially annoying in Dayz). I could write pages detailing the bugs, you get the idea.

2. Second most annoying thing is the interface and the interaction system. You have to scroll through a list of actions to change your weapon, get in a vehicle or perform some other mundane function which shouldn't be that complicated. There's a key for everything and then some. It's very clunky, slow and prone to you pressing the wrong button or doing something unintended. Controling your squad mates and telling them where to go, what to attack is tedious at best.

3. Clunky player movement? Even cars drive like crap and those are the easiest to control.

4. Inaccurate helicopter controls. Don't even get me started, whatever you read on the net, trust me. The heli controls are bad and make no sense. I have no idea what they were thinking when they decided that the helicopter would start acting like and airplane above 50 mph. I can fly no problem in flight sims and the Battlefield series. I even fly RC in real life. This is innacurate, plain and simple.

5. Devs had plenty of time to address these bugs/issues and this is a problem. What a bunch of underachievers. Their strategy is like this: For every new iteration/expansion, focus on adding more crap and complexity built on the same shoddy engine/interface and ignore all the bugs. Then collect money and develop the next uncooked iteration.

Arma2:OA isn't that much better, either. The missions bugs are fewer, but everything else is the same.

The bottom line: This is the kind of game you play because you know what to expect and you still want to play it because there isn't anything like it. You have to be a cult follower, or else you will hate it. The main reason you might get this is to play Dayz mod, which is great, but expect to be killed falling through floors, off ladders, killed by zombies walking through walls, etc... Definitely not for the casual gamer.

reviewText:
The good:  Very good warfare simulator with tons of options, weapons, accessories, vehicles, etc...
The bad  :  Very intense and comprehensive learning curve for those new to the series  (Flahpoint, Arma).

All in all I absolutely love this game.   Just like the real thing, the battles are drawn out, tactical, and a thinking mans game.   This game is not friendly to the run and gunning COD players, and that is what it's main draw is in my opinion.  Graphics are not bad for the time this was released, and when cranked up with view distance above 5000 it is quite stunning representation of ARMA maps.

Single player is quite lacking in my opinion,  but nobody should be buying this game for that reason.  The indepth mission editor and online multiplayer mods is what sells this game.   But you can have a good time learning the game in the campaign.  Thats about it tho...

All in all,  I recommend this game because I can enjoy a nice long battle, choose my involvement and position in  that battle, and not be a nervous wreck twitch shooting everything that moves....   From front level infantryman, to the pilot dropping players off at the front lines, everyone can find a place to be happy in multiplayer.

reviewText:
Amazing game. The Scope and Scale of it is just massive. No it's not like a run and gun CoD, or an Arcade Battlefield. The Trailer is a bit bad, but when you are playing a proper multiplayer mission, its just immersive. The Campaigns and scenarios have alot of content, and even then you have a huge editor to mess with in tons of different locations, easily 100s of sq KM big.

The Gameplay and controls can be quite clunky, but it's what makes it a tactical shooter, and a huge strategy game. It's really like playing those old school war strategys overhead, but as the units yourself.

The Graphics are still great for an old game, and you'll never have the feeling that its too dated to play. The realism features are amazing, with the gun ballistics and the vehicles.

While it may have the hardcore, slow realistic look to it, it has its fair share of of epic moments, one of my favourite is how the buildings collapse and how when air vehicles crash they leave huge ruptures in the ground.

Dont buy it if you are looking for a quick shooty bang bang game, if you're willing to be patient and put the effort in its a very good game.

reviewText:
Arma 2 is by no means a game for noobs or traditional FPS shooters. It instead caters to players who want a realistic military shooter. And realistic it is. Before playing any game, the player must properly plan their course of action with their team members, or hell will break loose. This aspect of the game is extremely fun and engaging. It's when the mission actually begins, however, that the game becomes quite unsatisfactory.

The gameplay is, unfortunately,  like a three legged horse trying to win a horse race while suffering with diabetes and terminal cancer. The sad reality is that the game's graphics are not up to par with the 2008 standard I'm used to, and the actual firefights are extremely unsatisfactory. The movement, strange screen bobbling, and clunky guns don't sound good, and their damage and recoil is questionable at most times.

To make matters even worse, the interface is clunky and not easy to learn. Me and my friend were struggling to determine how to coordinate several missions. I'm all for a detailed interface, but make the options relevant in the game. Movement is even worse, and feels sadly completely broken. There are also a handful of glitches that I encountered such as falling through maps and colliding with enemy units and not being able to separate again. The AI suffers from strange glitches as well, and don't respond well to the terrain.

The worst part of the game is the voice acting. Oh god... it sounds like they hired Joe at the bakery to do the voice acting, and it really shows. I have always been a stern believer in that voice acting should only be done if you have qualified voice actors who can do that job. If not, just having text is NOT a bad thing at all.

Overall, Arma 2 is not the realistic military shooter that you should choose. The only realistic thing you will find here is a damaged keyboard from anger issues. If it is a realistic military shooter that you seek, then Arma 3 should be your choice as they fixed almost all the items I have mentioned above.

Score: 3/10

reviewText:
The Basics: Military shooter with a focus on realism
Previous Time Spent: 46 minutes
Expectation of learning Curve: High
Why I bought this: The infamous Day-Z mod + a steam sale
My 3 Hours with the Game: After checking to see if any multiplayer servers were active, and finding them dead, I resigned myself to single player. I began with an intro scenario in which my compatriots and I were helicoptered in to an active battle zone, with the goal of moving about, shooting people, and holding territory. I played several other scenarios, and never gave the game the amount of effort or care needed to master it.

First Impressions: This is a frightening game that alternates between somewhat boring movement, and extremely dangerous combat. Combat feels quite realistically dangerous, without any sort of health bar, or clear explanation of how injuries work. In my first firefight, I got lucky for a bit before taking a shot, and being brought down. I didn't die however, and spent some time waiting for first aid before returning to the fight. In other fights, I seemed to take injuries that caused me to bleed (at a hard to discern rate), die instantly, or be knocked down, presumably wounded. Not taking cover, or generally acting like an action hero/video game character were recipes for disaster and death. Additionally, combat tended to take place at such a long distance that it was difficult to tell where the enemy was firing from.

My highlight: I eventually realized that the map covered an area much larger than my immediate combat zone, and in one of the missions decided to steal a pickup truck and leave. This actually worked, and I managed to make my way out of the combat zone (after taking a little bit of fire, resulting in a broken window). I followed the main dirt road out of the village we were supposed to be sweeping, and found myself in another village. This, and all subsequent villages were devoid of life, presumably ghost-towns fled due to the war I was taking part in. I drove some 3 km through farm villages before hitting a paved main road. From there, I drove through woods and mountains to the coast (stopping to swim in a pond). From the coast, I swam out to a small island and decided to end my 3 hour run as the unofficial lighthouse keeper of this empty country.

My verdict: This game works really well at what it's trying to do, but that isn't exactly to my taste. So, I do not regret picking it up, but I can't see myself playing beyond 3 hours. Next time I'll be covering the Day-Z mod.

reviewText:
The engine is very old and outdated, and even with Bohemia constantly updating and optimizing the game, it still runs poorly on modern computers. They stretched the engine to the very limits, but it's just too old to do much with.

As for the gameplay, the engine is still holding the game back. Compared to modern gameplay (and even real military combat) it's really slowpaced and clunky to control. The shooting mechanics are pretty in-depth and fairly fun though, but you will often find yourself getting killed with little indication simply because of the failures of the engine. There is little feedback in this game; shooting someone causes no movement or any kind of indication of pain or disability, so it's incredibly hard to tell if you are hitting and doing any real damage some times until they fall down with the prone animation or the death animation. You almost immediately notice just how many work-arounds they had to implement to get the engine to do what they want, sort of like how Blizzard had to work around their old engine for WoW.

As for the simulation side of things: it's probably the best you'll ever get to a fun simulation of combat without playing those really cheesey and un-fun military simulators out there. The game can be as realistic as you want, since you have to set the rules for yourself. Want military-grade training and cooperation with a heavy dose of roleplay? You might be interested in ShackTac. Want to just mess around and have fun without much serious RP? There are tons of those, but I recommend getting friends to play with for this.

Over all, the game is really showing its age even though it isn't that old. The technology wasn't ready for a game of this scale when it was released, and it shows, not to mention the really bad engine.
But despite these things, I think it's safe to say that this game is the most fun you can have in a cooperative video game. There is nothing like playing ACE with 3-7 friends on missions meant for 20-30 people. There is nothing like assaulting militia bases in Takistan with 3 of your best mates, going up against the odds well into the morning. There is no feeling similar to what you can get when you organize your close friends to all install ACE mod and playing it for the first time, helping eachother out of the ropes.

I can't recommend this game to anyone anymore, as ARMA III is now here and there is no reason to play this game anymore since the mods have all been updated for the new game. But rest assured: this game will always have a place deep in my heart.

I only have a few hours played here because there's no reason to launch ARMA II over Operation Arrowhead.

I don't believe I have ever had a more confusing experience. I really wanted to like this game. It's extremely ambitious in design and looks pretty solid in areas. Modes such as Armory are relatively fun and grand in scope; however, playing the game is a frustrating experience.

The controls are very strange and do not come to the player easily. You have to fiddle around with it to get it to your liking, which is easier said than done. Think about most first person shooter games with their controls: now remove aspects of sensitivity and general feeling of control on the weapon. I had a problem on more than one occassion where I died because I could not aim at the enemy at all. After going through the control menu, I selected a lock-on control scheme. Another problem I have is picking up weapons; it's very slow, and causes certain games (DayZ) to be incredulously hard to play because you end up getting caught off guard trying to get a weapon that you can't aim anyway.

reviewText:
Building on 10 years of constant engine development, ARMA II boasts the most realistic combat environment in the world. It models real world ballistics & round deflection, materials penetration, features a realtime day/night cycle and dynamic wind, weather and environmental effects. The simulation of a combat environment is so effective, the engine forms the basis for training simulators used by real armies the world over.

Although ARMA II is set in the fictional ex-soviet state of 'Chernarus' the gameworld is actually a 225 square kilometer chunk of the real world! ARMA II's highly detailed landscape is a meticulous facsimile of real terrain, modeled using extensive geographical data. This recreated region is brought to life with spectacular environmental effects and populated with dynamic civilian settlements and wildlife. Wild animals roam the atmospheric forests while the people of Chernarus try to live out their lives among the war-torn streets.

The 27th U.S. Marine Expeditionary Unit have been deployed to the former soviet country of Chernarus in this third installment in the series of award winning PC war simulators from Bohemia Interactive, creators of Operation Flashpoint*: Cold War Crisis and ARMA: Combat Operations.

Force Reconnaissance Team Razor are among the first to fight. This elite five-man team are about to fall down the rabbit hole, trapped in a war not only for control of the country, but the hearts and minds of its people. With the might of the USMC offshore and the Russians anxiously watching from the north, the stakes couldn't be higher. The fate of Chernarus is balanced on a razor's edge...

reviewText: Arma II is a commendable game on many levels.  It is open, it tries to be realistic, and in many ways it succeeds.  There are plausible scenarios, tons of weapons, interesting views and tactics.  But.  The UI is clunky, the controls are clunky the feel of the game itself is clunky and needlessly complex.  On top of these points, the dialogue and music are hardly compelling, in fact, they are like cheese on a soggy pizza.  Yes, it's technically pizza, and pizza is good, but this is some bad cheese.\n\nThe best part about Arma II is that you can mod Arma II.  You can add extra toppings to make the whole thing a little more palatable.  Can I recommend Arma II as a buy that is used to create a fun gaming experience?  Absolutely.  Can I recommend it as a stand-alone product?  Unlikely.  This review reflects Arma II as a standalone game, and as a standalone piece of software it gets a 6.8/10.  Mediocre at best despite its grand aspirations.

reviewText:
Arma 2 review..... Kinda.

After playing 114 minutes of Arma2 I realize now why I got it for $4 on a Steam sale.

It's so amazingly clunky and buggy it's almost impossible to hit anything. Felt like I was playing an alpha version. Not to mention the controls are so weird I don't even know where to begin. One of the few impressive things about this game is map and terrain size, as the game environments are massive. But besides that, the dialogue and interface for issuing commands to my team were barely functional since my team acts like drunken, glitched out morons that often caused me to fail objectives.

The graphics are total crap on default settings, and I was only able to play on maxed settings to see anything more than 3 feet infront of me. By default everything is like looking through someone else's glasses that make everything super blurry. I had to max everything out to see the textures clearly without any blurring. But what I saw looked more like they were intentionally blurry, and there's no way that can seriously be the way the game is intended to be played.

Maybe there are other great things about this game, but I'm not willing to go that far yet since I have many more games to play on my list. Perhaps I'll revisit this game at a later date. But for now, I'm not going to wander into megaglitchland again for a while. Sorry for the negative review.
